raw_text:
Will Tory tax cuts lift spirits?
 
 Michael Howard has finally revealed the full scale of his planned Tory tax cuts.
 
 Should he win the next general election, he has earmarked £4 billion that will be used to reduce taxes - although he still will not say which or how. This was the pre-election message many in his party have been pressing for and voters, he believes, will warm to. At its simplest, it is saying: "Vote Tory and you can have it both ways". Not only would his government stick to Labour spending plans on core public services, including health and education, it would increase spending on defence, police and pensions. And even after that was done, it would still have enough left over for a tax cut equivalent to about a penny off the basic rate of income tax.
 
 All the money would come from its £35 billion efficiency savings which would see the axe taken to bureaucracy, waste and the civil service. Of that, £23 billion would go on spending plans, with £8 billion to fill the black hole left, they claim, by Gordon Brown, and the rest going in tax cuts.
 
 Neither Mr Howard nor Mr Letwin would say exactly how they would use that cash, although a cut in the basic rate seems unlikely. Ideas already floated include raising tax thresholds and abolishing or reducing inheritance tax, although some in the Tory party are urging Mr Howard to announce something more eye-catching before the election. As the Tory leader declared, the aim of the exercise is to open up a real economic policy divide between Labour and the Tories. "At this election, people will have a clear choice between Mr Blair who will waste more and tax more and the Conservative party which will give value for money and tax less," he said.
 
 It is a move back towards an almost traditional Tory message which previously suggested Labour was the party of tax rises and the Conservatives the party of tax cuts.
 
 The extension of that, however, was that Labour was also seen as the party of big spending on the public services while the Tories were the cutters. And that is where one of the problems lies for Mr Howard - can he persuade sceptical voters that they really can have it both ways with bigger spending on public services AND lower taxes? He insists he will not promise anything before the election that he cannot deliver if put into Downing Street. Labour, needless to say, claim his planned £35bn efficiency savings simply don't add up and that those sorts of figures are fantasy.
 
 One of New Labour's greatest successes before the historic 1997 election was to persuade voters, business and the City that it could be trusted to run the economy. So far that has not faced any real challenge, but independent analysts now claim a third New Labour government would be forced to either increase taxation or taxes to plug a black hole it has at the centre of its finances. Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrats are committed to increasing taxes for the most well off to finance their spending proposals launched earlier in the day. So, Mr Howard hopes his message will start to hit home during this unofficial election campaign and that his poll ratings might finally lift off the floor. And, while other issues like the Iraq war and trust will play a major part in that campaign, it is likely - and the prime minister probably hopes - that the economy will be the deciding factor.
llama3.2:1b: Michael Howard has revealed plans to cut taxes of £4 billion if he wins the next general election.
The funds would reduce tax rates for core public services like health and education, while also increasing spending on defence, police, and pensions.
The cuts would come from efficiency savings of £35 billion, which could include raising tax thresholds and abolishing or reducing inheritance tax.
Howard says the aim is to create a "real economic policy divide" between Labour and the Tories by making it clear that he will reduce taxes more than Labour.
llama3.2:3b: Michael Howard has announced £4 billion worth of planned Tory tax cuts to be implemented if his party wins the next general election.
The money would come from an efficiency savings plan, with £23 billion going towards spending plans and £8 billion left over for tax cuts.
Labour claims the efficiency savings don't add up, while independent analysts say a New Labour government may need to increase taxation or cut public services to balance its finances.
gemma2:2b: Michael Howard has announced plans for £4 billion in tax cuts if he wins the next election.
These cuts would come from efficiencies gained through reducing bureaucracy and waste.
He aims to position his party as offering a balance of public service spending and lower taxes, contrasting with Labour's vision.
However, doubts are raised about the feasibility of achieving this balancing act.
The Conservative Party faces challenges convincing voters that their economic plan can deliver on both promises.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Will Tory tax cuts increase spirits?
A £4 billion plan to reduce taxes earmarked for Labour plans on public services but not specifically Labour spending plans.
Critics suggest the government still won't specify how the money would be used, making it unclear whether it's a tax cut or an increase in spending on other areas.

Despite his pre-election message backing Labour, Mr. Howard wants voters to feel more comfortable with the idea of a bigger tax cut by promising to invest £35 billion in efficiency savings for the government.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Michael Howard plans to cut taxes by £4 billion if elected, aiming for "value for money" by reducing bureaucracy and spending more on defense, police, and pensions while maintaining existing public service funding levels and some tax cuts.
This move challenges Labour's traditional stance on taxation but faces skepticism from both New Labour supporters and independent analysts worried about future fiscal problems.
qwen2.5:3b: Michael Howard has announced planned £4 billion Tory tax cuts for the next general election, aimed at increasing spending on defence, police, and pensions while also lowering taxes through efficiency savings from £35 billion.
The cuts could include raising thresholds or reducing inheritance tax, but a penny cut to the basic rate seems unlikely.
Critics argue that Labour will have more efficient finances with lower taxation.
Howard aims to differentiate the Tories as economically responsible compared to Labour, which is seen as increasing spending on public services while also increasing taxes.
Polls suggest this economic message may help lift Tory ratings during the election campaign.
opencoder:1.5b:
This summarizes the following key points:

- Will Tory tax cuts lift spirits?
- He has finally revealed the full scale of his planned Tory tax cuts.
- Should he win the next general election, he plans to earmark £4 billion for further tax cuts.
- This was the pre-election message many in his party have been pressing for and voters expect will warm to.
- Mr Howard believes that after all these money should be used to reduce taxes - yet, it is still a cut that seems unlikely.
- He also wants to raise tax thresholds and abolish or reduce inheritance tax.
- He was also urged by some members of the Tory party to announce something more eye-catching before the election.
- The aim of the exercise is to open up a real economic policy divide between Labour and the Tories.
- Mr Howard's main message aims to encourage a clear decision between Labour and the Conservatives.
- After the historic 1997 election, Labour claimed substantial financial gains but the City was not satisfied with this result.
Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrats have shown concern for the increase in taxes due to their spending plans and are committed to finance more efficient and cost-effective solutions.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary above captures the main ideas of the text, preserving key concepts such as:

1.
The purpose of the text: to provide an overview of the main points made in a longer piece of writing.
The main idea or central argument: that the Tory government will increase spending on public services and reduce taxes, but not necessarily promise anything before the election.
Key details: the amount of money that would be cut from the civil service budget, the level of taxation, and the specific policies implemented by the Labour party.
The tone: informative, neutral, and factual, without any emotional or persuasive language.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Michael Howard's proposed £4 billion tax cuts aim to reduce taxes across Labour's core services, including health and education, while injecting more money for defense, police, and pensions.
He claims the savings will cover this, but voters won't know exactly how they'll use it, with a focus on creating economic divide.
Howard is pushing back on a traditional message where Labour was seen as cutting taxes and Conservative as spending.
The campaign emphasizes both public services and tax cuts, aiming to make voters aware of both sides.
tinyllama:1.1b: The author summarizes the article about Michael Howard's planned tax cuts for the general election campaign.

The article describes the full scale of his plan to reduce taxes, including a £4 billion budget, which is used to decrease taxes by reducing spending on core public services like health and education while increasing spending on defeating deficits from Labour plans.
This, according to the author, could lead to a tax cut in the form of a lower basic rate of income tax.

The article also mentions the possibility of implementing policies like raising taxes on buraucrats or cutting waste, as well as a plan to increase spending plans for specific expenses by £8 billion and cut costs for others.

Despite the author's initial skepticism towards Howard's promise to balance the budget while still increasing taxes, he notes that independent analysts now predict a third New Labour government would be forced to either increase taxation or taxes to plug a black hole at the center of its finances.

The author speculates that the message of "value for money and tax less" may finally hit home during Howard's unofficial election campaign, but notes that other issues like the Iraq war and trust will still be important in determining vote choice.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Michael Howard's announced Tory tax cuts aim to address the widening gap between the haves and have-nots by increasing spending on public services and cutting taxes for individuals.
This move back towards traditional Tory economic policy aligns with previous assertions that Labour is the party of tax rises and the Conservatives the party of tax cuts.
The extension of this idea, however, was that Labour was also seen as the party of big spending on public services while the Tories were the cutters.
This contrast between these two parties' priorities for public expenditure suggests a divide in voter sentiment between the Conservatives and Labour.
However, one of the major problems faced by Mr Howard is ensuring that his plan can be executed effectively and maintains balance with other policy areas like the economy and international relations.
The current state of political finances is likely to make it challenging for Mr Howard to deliver the £35bn efficiency savings without jeopardizing the public services they serve.
While this may seem like a large amount of money, many experts argue that these cuts could result in significant job losses and reduced access to essential services.
In addition to this, it is also likely to increase taxation for individuals earning above £20,000 per year, effectively affecting the middle classes.

The Liberal Democrats, on the other hand, have proposed increasing taxes for the highest-earners to finance their spending proposals, which could potentially disrupt Mr Howard's plans for reducing taxes.

Although this election campaign is still in its early stages, it appears that the Conservatives may need to adjust their message or risk alienating a large portion of voters who currently support them.
phi:2.7b: The article discusses Michael Howard's planned Tory tax cuts of £4 billion if he wins the next general election.
He has earmarked this money to reduce taxes while also spending on core public services like health and education, as well as increasing defense, police, and pension spending.
He plans to fund these cuts by making £35 billion in efficiency savings, with £23 billion going towards spending plans and £8 billion filling the tax-deficit left by Gordon Brown's policies.
Mr. Howard intends to use this money to raise tax thresholds and abolish or reduce inheritance taxes while also promising to give value for money and lower taxes.
However, critics claim that his planned efficiency savings are not realistic and question whether he can deliver on his promises.
Meanwhile, Labour claims that they will have to either increase taxes or raise taxes to make up for their spending plans.
The Liberal Democrats plan to increase taxes for the most well-off to finance their spending proposals.
Mr. Howard hopes his message will convince voters of his economic policies and that the economy will be the deciding factor in the election.
orca-mini:3b: Tory tax cuts could provide relief for taxpayers, but its effectiveness depends on how they are implemented.
The £4 billion to reduce taxes would be earmarked by Michael Howard, but he still won't say which or how.

He claims that his government's £35 billion efficiency savings would fill the black hole left by Gordon Brown and give enough money for a tax cut equivalent to about a penny off the basic rate of income tax.
However, neither Mr Howard nor David Cameron have promised exactly how they will use the £23 billion from efficiency savings to fill the black hole.
Labour's stance is that they would increase taxes or cut public services to plug the black hole.
The Liberal Democrats also propose increasing taxes for the most well-off to finance their spending proposals.
hermes3:3b: Michael Howard plans Tory tax cuts worth £4bn if elected, after promising efficiency savings of £35bn to cover spending on core services and defence, against Labour's tax rises and increased spending.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Michael Howard plans £4 billion tax cuts if he wins the next general election as part of his attempt to provide a clear economic policy divide between Labour and the Tories.
The money would come from £35 billion efficiency savings, with £23 billion allocated for spending plans and the rest going towards tax cuts.
Both Labour and the Liberal Democrats have committed to increasing taxes for the well-off to finance their respective spending proposals.
Howard's message aims to resonate with voters who may be skeptical about the party simultaneously having bigger spending on public services and lower taxes.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Michael Howard has announced £4 billion in Tory tax cuts if he wins the next election, funded by £35 billion in efficiency savings from reducing bureaucracy and waste.
His plan maintains Labour’s spending on core public services while increasing funding for defence, police, and pensions.
However, he has not specified which taxes will be cut, though possibilities include raising tax thresholds or reducing inheritance tax.
Howard aims to contrast Tory policies with Labour’s, portraying the Conservatives as offering lower taxes and better value for money.
Labour disputes the feasibility of these savings, arguing the figures are unrealistic.
While New Labour has maintained economic trust since 1997, analysts suggest a third Labour government may need to raise taxes to cover financial shortfalls.
The Liberal Democrats, meanwhile, propose tax increases for the wealthy to fund their policies.
Howard hopes his economic message will boost his poll ratings, though other issues like the Iraq war and trust will also influence the election outcome.
stablelm2:1.6b: Tory tax cuts are planned by Michael Howard if he wins the next general election, with £4 billion earmarked for reduced taxes.
This would come from efficiency savings of £8 billion on spending plans, leaving enough left over for a cut equivalent to about 1p off the basic rate of income tax.
However, neither Howard nor Letwin have specified exactly how they will use this cash.
The aim is to create an economic policy divide between Labour and the Tories, with Labour being seen as the party of big spending on public services while the Conservatives were cutters.
Despite this message hitting home during the unofficial election campaign, persuading sceptical voters that they can have it both ways remains a challenge for Howard.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Michael Howard has unveiled £4 billion for Tory tax cuts if his party wins the next general election, with plans to use efficiency savings of £35 billion primarily for increased public spending on defence, police, pensions, and core services like health and education.
The remaining funds would fund a tax cut equivalent to about one penny off the basic rate of income tax.
However, Howard has not specified how these tax cuts would be implemented, with options like raising tax thresholds or abolishing inheritance tax being considered.
This move aims to present a clear economic policy contrast between the Conservatives and Labour, emphasizing value for money and lower taxes despite increased public spending.
Critics argue that Howard's efficiency savings projections are unrealistic, and independent analysts predict New Labour would face tax increases to cover its financial shortfall.
The Liberal Democrats also propose taxing the wealthy for their spending plans.
Howard hopes this messaging will improve his party's poll ratings during the unofficial election campaign, with economic issues expected to play a decisive role.
